item.title: Weeknotes 36
item.description:
Week 36

Weeknotes

  • Managing Distractions

Managing Distractions

I fail at managing distractions A LOT. When a fellow developer needs my help, I’ll help. Even though I probably should finish my current train of thought before I switch contexts.

I feel like that’s the trick though; switching contexts successfully. If you can switch context, finish the new task, than switch back seamlessly… you’re amazing. Most of us, I imagine, can’t do that.

Part of my problem is how I use my To Do list, Things. I kind of wished there was a way to mark something as “current” or “in progress”, and only have the ability to mark one todo as such. It would also keep a memory of the order you worked on tasks. So, switching from task A to task B would be visible to you when you finished Task B and needed to return to task A. It’s also not very easy to enter notes in Things. I love things and this is probably an edge case for many todo apps. This just means I need to have some sort of “context journal”.

I started that this week. I’ll report back on how it’s helping.

item.title: Weeknotes 35
item.description:
Week 35

Weeknotes

  • App Builds
  • CommonJS

App builds

As an application grows, especially in its infancy, there needs to be some processes in place to help achieve and maintain goals for the build process.

We recently split off all our web components into their own repo and this caused all kinds of madness. It was something we couldn’t foresee and, therefore, it wasn’t something we could have done better.

Still, when something we built ends up being a blocker for current work, there needs to be some sort of AAR where we figure out what went wrong and how to avoid it in the future.

We don’t have a dev ops person… well, not explicitly anyway. I wouldn’t say we should have one, but we should remove someone from a sprint when something huge happens, something like changing our repos this extensively. This person’s sole responsibility is to monitor and maintain the build. They should document and test the build until it satisfactory. A lot of people will have a problem with this because the velocity of the next sprint will be negatively affected. It’s a tough situation. I’m curious how similar size teams handle this situation.

CommonJS

I had to familiarize myself with how CommonJS works a bit this week. I don’t mean the require or exports keywords but more how it looks for files and which thing to use when there could be multiples. Maybe I’m not looking right but I couldn’t seem to find much on this type of information.

item.title: Weeknotes 34
item.description:
Week 34

Weeknotes

  • StealJS yet again
  • Promises/Deferreds
  • Learning about WebWorkers

StealJS yet again

I spent some time working on the build process for The Art Project. It seems like i was using the incorrect distribution of CanJS. Once i switched to AMD, things started working. Im still having problems though. Now the stache plugin is returning some funky errors. Still debugging what the errors actually mean.

A question i have to bring up is why Steal doesn’t report better errors. Ill explain later as I’m still trying to make sure I m on the right track.

Promises and deferreds

I was working on a dialog implementation using can.component. Example usage of the component’s api was given to me and I just had to build it. Im glad i was given these examples as it seriously open my mind to the real possibilities of deferreds.

Being able to use reject and resolve to trigger different callback without having to pass the callbacks to the dialog itself is genius. Ill be adding this to our component library asap.

Web Workers

I read a primer on web workers this week and I’m curious if they can be used to compile templates. I am using a pseudo model to manage a calendar widget, I bet this can be refactored to be a web worker as well.

It’s crazy how much the browser api and ECMA script combined have essentially become a programming environment like native mobile apps. Its cool and exciting, but also a little crazy.

item.title: Weeknotes 33
item.description:
Week 33

  • Bitovi Retreat

Bitovi Retreat

This was my first retreat with the team and it was AMAZING. The first part of the week was basically a hackathon where we tried to work on stuff that we had proposed back in December. Most being tools to improve our Open Source products.

The project I worked on was building a component library for CanJS. Other teams worked on improving DocumentJS, CanJS, and more. The component library ended up using many of the improvements to help present the work in a useful way. DocumentJS, for example, was great for creating the API docs that included demos of each component.

After the work week, significant others were flown out for the weekend where we explored and enjoyed Austin Texas.

It was an amazing experience. There were long days but I can’t imagine a better group of people to spend loooong days with while getting some very cool stuff built.

item.title: Weeknotes 32
item.description:
Week 32

  • Scope creep

Scope Creep

I export my tasks from Jira and other work task management tools into Things. It’s easier because I can break up tasks into sizes that work better for me.

I noticed this past sprint that I added a single task to my workload. When I broke it out into individual tasks, it turned into three tasks. I then added documentation and test updates, which made it five tasks.

After working on the first task, I had questions on changes which resulted in two more tasks. These new tasks, after the final product was reviewed, resulted in a five more tasks. Keep in mind these are all minimal tasks. One could be something like “change color for text” while another could be something more involved but still as small as it could be. Something like “resolve merge conflicts”.

This is really normal and I’m glad I aggregate my lists this way, specifically because it helps me respond to scope changes like this.

It’s also interesting to see a task list turn into a hydra monster. One task turned into three which turned into five, which turned into seven, which is still not done and could continue growing.

Keeping track of these monsters is important, at some point (if it continues to grow), the wheel needs to get squeaky.

item.title: Weeknotes 31
item.description:
Week 31

  • Six Months at Bitovi
  • CanJS Control
  • CanJS and Steal Part 2

Six Months at Bitovi

I had my six month checkin this week. The realization that it’s been six months was weird. Time flies, man.

The past six months have been amazing. My desire to learn more and improve is constantly satisfied and challenged. I get to work with some bad ass people working on some bad ass projects. I’m pretty excited that it’s only been six months, that means I’m having fun.

CanJS Control

I’m trying out this pattern where, instead of adding more features to a component, I add the new feature as a can.Control that is designed to work specifically with the component. Lately, we’ve been adding feature after feature to some components and they’re getting harder and harder to maintain.

Even after six months, I’m still learning new things about our open source tools like CanJS. It feels like this is a good solution but I can’t be certain until after it gets used for a bit.

My other thought was to build additional functionality for a component within another discrete component. Then, if this functionality is needed, all one has to do is add the other component and target the original component. I’m not sure how the linking part would work so I decided to stick with the can.Control for now. We’ll see how it works out.

CanJS and Steal Part 2

After researching other CanJS projects, I figured out my problem with getting fixtures to work in my art project. Using the new release of CanJS, I also had to update the paths in the Steal config file. Changing the paths meant updating every file I had old paths in. Once this was done, everything worked GREAT.

Now, I’m having problems with my routes, unrelated to the above though. I’m still getting familiar with how to write solid routes so it’s a little hard to debug. Also, the build isn’t actually building (I’m using Steal to load dependancies in the browser), and I need to verify my routes are good. So the first step is to make sure everything builds nicely.

We’re heading to Austin this week for a Bitovi retreat (super excited!) so I’m going miss this weeks Code for Cary Meetup. I’m going to try and get a build working so we can have a prototype site running by the end of the week.

item.title: Weeknotes 30
item.description:
Week 30

  • Working outside

Working outside

We had our first nice-ish day this year. It was nice enough to leave the windows open all day and even sit on the porch and do some work. There are days where I miss the immediate interaction one can get when working at an office. Collaboration works so much cleaner, I think, in this environment.

Remote work isn’t worse, it’s just different. This collaboration still exists, just over a wire. I don’t think it takes a “specific type of person” to be a remote worker, but it definitely requires a certain mindset. The rewards for being able to work this way are bountiful. One such benefit is working on your porch. ;)

item.title: Weeknotes 29
item.description:
Week 29

  • CanJS and StealJS

CanJS and StealJS

I got a chance to work on the Art Finder project for Code for Cary and I thought I would continue getting prototypes working.

For module loading, I am using StealJS. It’s the second time I’ve used it in a project with CanJS where I am using fixtures. I’m a little behind on the two tools as far as how they work with each other. The biggest problem is StealJS chokes on can.fixture.js because CanJS 2.1.4 doesn’t work with newest StealJS versions.

I’m really bummed out by this and surprised. The solution is to use the CanJS minor branch but that causes other errors in my code and fixtures still won’t load. This app won’t be live any time soon so there’s no real rush but it’s a little frustrating.

We’ll see how that goes.

item.title: Weeknotes 28
item.description:
Week 28

  • Logging time
  • StealJS with CanJS

Logging time

I wonder who really benefits from logging time. There are rarely tools that make it easy to capture time spent on projects, render time reports, and add on other business specific options. Never mind being cost effective.

I’ve spent a lot of time logging time and I was wondering how often time tracking is actually useful beyond the time spent tracking the actual time spent. More often I hear legal reasons than billing reasons and almost rarely hear productivity reasons.

Just sayin’.

Firebase’s Firepad

I built a quick app using Firebase’s Firepad tool. Firepad is a notepad with versioning (ish) and collaboration while using Firebase as the backend. It’s pretty neat to have all that functionality baked in and not have to think about it.

Unfortunately, it doesn’t lend well to module loaders. This is fine but I want to make builds of it so I can use it in different places and only need to change a few options for each build.

I found myself working on separating each of it’s internal tools into files so I can require them into the main file. This is great as I am learning a lot about module loaders and, specifically, StealJS.

item.title: Weeknotes 27
item.description:
Week 27

  • CanJS and Steal

CanJS scaffold

I spun up a project scaffold from scratch for the Code for Cary Art Finder Project. There isn’t really a good scaffolder for CanJS, unfortunately. There are a couple repos out there with Yeoman generators but they are a bit outdated in that they don’t work well with can.Component. That is to say, they work they just don’t generate blank components.

Either way, I thought it would be a good idea to put into practice what I have learned on CanJS project structure. I’m pretty happy with it and aim to post the project on Github soon.

I would like to actually keep this structure clean and make it into a repo that I can use later. I’ve never created a Yeoman generator but I hear they’re super easy. Might take a stab at that as well.

item.title: Weeknotes 26
item.description:
Week 26

  • PhantomJS
  • Code for Cary

PhantomJS

I have to research this more, but as I struggle with writing tests for my code, I have this recurring thought: why do we test code in a browser environment that really isn’t an end-user browser? If it’s a module loader issue, fine. But I suspect it isn’t. Integration tests should be run on the different browsers the project has identified as key browsers.

I could just be complaining or missing something important. I’m skeptical, though. More research is required.

Code for Cary

This past Tuesday (the 10th), Code for Cary met to listen to a request from the Arts Center folks. They essentially want to wrap their artwork database with a useful interface for citizens. There’s a few different projects by other Brigades doing essentially the same thing but none of them are at the level Cary needs.

I’m still going over my notes about the project but I’m really excited to see what we can build for them. Cary, and many many other cities, have beautiful artwork that citizens can enjoy - if only they knew about them or how to find them.

item.title: Weeknotes 25
item.description:
Week 25

  • Keeping lists organized

Keeping lists organized

I’ve been using Things a lot in the past few months. I’ve tried so many To Do apps and methods. I’ll admit that I never dove in the deep end of Getting Things Done. I thought GTD was just too “bossy” for me. I really liked Todo.txt because of its simplicity. I tried plain pencil and paper but it got too cluttered.

After downloading Things, though, I researched GTD more and realized how powerful and simple it really is. Coupled with Things itself, which is very clean and well built, I’ve never had To Do’s so managed and within reach. To Do lists are different for everyone and there’s so much talk out there about how to manage lists that I won’t go into it.

I wanted to talk about being forced to have multiple lists on different mediums. For example, a client has the project’s tasks in Jira. I have my personal stuff in Things. My wife puts the shopping list in FetchNotes. I fight the urge to just make everyone use Things. Not that it would do me any good since you can’t really share items in Things…

I found that the “inboxing” time is important with keeping this madness under control. I go through my different lists and add what needs adding.

It’s pretty simple and fairly effective. There’s issues with “on-the-fly” situations like shopping lists but I adjust based on the situation. The point is, though, that these situations are minimized.

item.title: Weeknotes 24
item.description:
Week 24

  • Audio notes

Audio notes

I bought a recorder a while back mostly for personal audio journaling but also for an amature podcast I do with a friend. It feels weird recording yourself, I’m not a scientist or a researcher or a coroner so I don’t really have a need for this kind of habit. That is, until I recorded my thoughts when I ran into a difficult programming problem.

More often then not, there is someone on-line that I can bounce ideas off of at work. But sometimes there isn’t someone available or sometimes I’m not at my computer and I’m just idly thinking of the problem. It was during one of these moments that I decided to speak my thoughts out loud.

There’s some real power with speaking out your thoughts. It might look a little nutty, but it’s extremely helpful. I’m not sure what this phenomenon is, but it seems like the brain processes the thoughts differently once their out of the realm of thought.

Try it the next time your stuck.

item.title: Weeknotes 23
item.description:
Week 23

  • Agile thoughts
  • Goals for the week

Agile thoughts

I like any method that revolves itself around iteration and self analyzation. Agile is great with these concepts. On the other hand, it doesn’t cease to frustrate how often people try to figure out problems other’s have experienced and solved. I know that every team is different and every project is different, but I don’t agree that teams should spend time figuring out a solved problem as if the problem wasn’t solved already. I guess what I’m saying is I think teams should recognize there is a problem, which teams seem to do well, and table it until someone (if not everyone on the team) can research the problem some more. Then come back and hash it out.

Goals for the week

I suck at git rebase. I don’t understand it, I don’t know what use cases it’s for, etc. I will become more familiar with it this week.

item.title: Weeknotes 22
item.description:
Week 22

  • Travel

Travel

I’ve been out of town this week for a client and I noticed a few things on this trip that I hadn’t noticed before on previous trips. Specifically to do with the flight itself. I heard about “man-spreading” on trains the other day. I was a little perturbed at how this isn’t a rule on planes, too. Ugh.

I have a standing desk at home and it feels great to stand all day. When I’m traveling, I’ve noticed that I spend a lot more time sitting because most places default to sitting environments - and rightly so, this is how most people work. Still, I am wondering if it’s possible to take a small portable standing desk with me next time. And if so, I wonder if it’s possible to not look like a weirdo when you bust out your folding standing desk.

I’ve started creating a wish list in Amazon that contain things that I’ve found are great for traveling. A portable surge protector with built in USB ports, for example. We’ll see how it evolves as I continue to travel.

item.title: Weeknotes 21
item.description:
Week 20

  • Metalsmith
  • Goals for the week

Metalsmith

Metalsmith is a JavaScript static site generator. The site also says it can scaffold and automate processes. It’s very similar to Gulp in that it uses pipes (called use in Metalsmith) and, obviously, it uses streams. Metalsmith can indeed be used to scaffold applications but I don’t know why anyone would use that in client work with more heavy communities like Gulp and Grunt.

Still, I tried using Gulp to build a static site and found it somewhat cumbersome and difficult. Metalsmith seems to handle this task effortlessly. I’m using it now to build a really simple photoblog site and I find it more flexible than Wintersmith as well.

Wintersmith’s biggest downfall, with me at least, was it’s inability to handle drafts. A plugin would have to be written in order to handle it. Metalsmith is the same. The difference, though, is that writing a plugin for Metalsmith is sooo much easier. That and there’s already a plugin to handle drafts! ;)

I’ve run into a few problems with Metalsmith because of the way I want to do things, and all I have to do is write a plugin for it. I wanted to change the date format and couldn’t find an easy plugin for that, so I wrote a quick plugin that copies and formats the date. It’s not a very good, reusable plugin, but it does the job for now.

The only weird issue I’ve run into that doesn’t rub me right is pagination of posts. I don’t want to use Handlebars and I’m trying to figure out how to paginate without switching my templating engine.

Also, the pagination and custom link plugins are very order dependent. But, that kinda makes sense, I think.

Goals for the week

I am using Things to manage my Todo lists. I added all my little sites as tags and created a Website project. I am populating it with all the updates I want to make to my sites. This week, I would like to start whittling the list down.

item.title: Weeknotes 20
item.description:
Week 20

  • Catching Up
  • Being mobile
  • Goals for the week

Catching Up

Technically, this is not week 20, I am not interested in calculating what week it really is. We fail, we get back up and clear the dust, and we keep moving forward.

Life has continued to move in the past few months. I attended a CanJS meetup, I hope to be able to help out more often with the meetup. I’m working on building something useful for my wife to help with her homeschooling. Work itself is proving to be fun, hard, and rewarding.

Being mobile

I have spent the past couple weeks with family in California. The biggest problem I’ve run into is not having ready access to wireless internet (Seriously, who doesn’t have Wi-fi anymore!?) I resolved this using my wireless hotspot which works great! Except I still like to watch things on Hulu and Netflix and sync my Dropbox and update the apps on my phone, etc. These activities have forced me to up our data limit.

Other than internet access, the only other problem is finding a quiet place to work. Coffee joints here aren’t too abundant and the kids can be, well, loud. Next time I need to travel like this, I’ll probably scope out some coworking offices before hand. It will probably be cheaper and less stressful.

Goals for the week

I’m catching up on all my little web homes. This week’s goal is to simple update all my sites with one item. This could be an article or something simpler.

item.title: Weeknotes 19
item.description:
Week 19

  • The Cary Updates
  • Goals for the week

The Cary Updates

You can see the main updates on the Code for Cary page.

I like the idea of abstracting the scraper tool from the scraping steps. The page we scrape can change over time and may not lend itself to being scraped easily. Also, we might need to scrape other pages to verify our data. For these reasons I want to build a tool that can read a configuration file, process it into commands, then do the actual scrape. The file will also tell the tool how to build the data it scrapes.

I need to work out the structure of the config file so I know what needs to be built but I’m thinking of starting small and just trying to make something basic. Then, as I continue with The Cary, I can refactor as needed.

Goals for the week

I’m in training in Chicago all week so just focusing on absorbing as much as possible.

item.title: Weeknotes 18
item.description:
Week 18

  • Never stop learning
  • CanJS and Firebase
  • Goals for the week

Never stop learning

I was watching ‘3 Days to Kill’ the other night. I’m a huge Luc Besson fan, ever since Leon (more widely known as ‘The Professional’). 3 Days to Kill was ok, it was entertaining. It has nothing to do with web development but there was a moment in the film that gave me pause regarding the progression of experiences and wisdom in our lives.

There’s a scene where Kevin Costner’s character is feeling really bad for himself, sitting on a bridge in Paris, eating Chinese food by himself. I thought, here’s this bad ass CIA guy who thought he had a solid grasp of his world. But in this moment, he knows nothing.

What I like about this movie is that it goes against the cliche, “You can’t teach an old dog new tricks”. Obviously, we get a happy ending for Kevin Costner after he learned to reassess what really was important in his life. There is a more important message being displayed which is, family is the most important thing. But let’s focus on the Old-dog-learns-new-trick aspect.

In the technology world, the most important skill to have is learning. Apparently, this goes double for professional hit-men/CIA/secret agent dads. But for people working with technology, there are moments where I get frustrated that I have to learn something new (it feels like very week these days). But once this new thing is learned and understood, I feel like He-man branding his sword high in the air; powerful and ready for the next challenge.

CanJS and Firebase

After building that quick CanJS page last week, I thought I’d take it a step further and build a CMS using Firebase as the backend. I previously had trouble getting CanJS to talk with Firebase using can.Model. After a few weeks of working at Bitovi and facing the different CanJS challenges, as well as reviewing the CanJS documentation, I was able to figure out a solution.

There aren’t any editing capabilities but the exciting part is it took me less than a day to build what I have so far. The next step is getting the live binding in CanJS to auto update the local Firebase data.

Goals for the week

I wasn’t able to spend a lot of time with Document JS, pretty much only what I need for work. I figured this will be an ongoing thing, learning Document JS as well as our other open source projects, specifically StealJS.

  • Connect live binding to Firebase
  • Write article on experience with CanJS + Firebase.

item.title: Weeknotes 17
item.description:
Week 17

  • Changing routines
  • Learning Can JS
  • Goals for the week

Changing routines

I liked finishing my weeks with weeknotes. I noticed that I started Monday with little context and wondered if weeknotes could help with that.

I’d like to be able to start my week with some goals that come from these. I normally have a small list of goals for the week but that usually includes house to-do’s and work to-do’s, not skill-leveling-up to-do’s. So, I thought I’d try switching my week notes to Mondays instead.

The problem with changing your routine, though, is that it breaks your routine! Monday morning I was struggling with trying to remember something I had to do that day. I didn’t remember what it was until late that night. That alone is a great learning experience: try not to change your routine, if you really have to, set yourself up for success by creating reminders or something similar that will help you transition and rebuild that routine.

Learning CANJS

My first two weeks at Bitovi have been two weeks of non-stop learning. It’s been great.

Last week, I decided that I had enough confidence to try something simple with CanJS. So, I created a very simple display of data using components. I am going to clean out some of my personal data from it and make the code a bit more generic. Once that’s done, I’ll push the repo and write up a post of what I did. It’s nothing profound but it helped me review what I’ve learned and cement a lot of the concepts.

Goals for the week

  • Push update to my CanJS practice app
  • Learn about DocumentJS, our open source JavaScript project documentation builder.

Documentation is a pet-peeve of mine. Its a great opportunity to contribute to a project that can help other’s build helpful documentation for their projects.

item.title: Weeknotes 16
item.description:
Week 16

  • First week completed

First week completed

Change is sometimes difficult, but always enriching. This first week at Bitovi has been amazing. My brain hurts… but in a good way. I consider myself a pretty smart fellow; I don’t have a ton of experience but I learn quickly… very quickly.

This week, though, challenged my ability to learn. The last time I felt this challenged was when I took my first web application development position. It’s so different and complex that it took me a while to get caught up. On the one hand, I have this level of challenging work and very experienced peers. On the other hand, I have this gratifying feeling of learning new things and becoming a better engineer. And just like before, it will take me some time to get caught up, but when I do, it will be glorious.

Change can be so difficult that it can cause feelings of insecurity and fear. This, in turn, increases the risk of failure. Now imagine a place that understands this dynamic and does everything it can to make sure that people feel welcome and free to express their difficulties. That’s Bitovi, a place with Bitovians.

Yes, change can be and usually is hard but when you’re surrounded by good people that care and want each other to succeed, the only way to fail is to stop trying.

It’s great to be a Bitovian.

item.title: Weeknotes 15
item.description:
Week 15

  • Last Day
  • Scraping with Cheerio
  • MongoDB

Last Day

Finished my last day at KSS. Good times there. It’s always sad to end a relationship. I still would like to maintain the individual relationships I made and even the organizational relationship as well. What I’m trying to say is that the relationship that I had between myself and the employer is done and that makes me feel a little bummed out. You spend all this time building relationships with people and the work itself and then bam, it’s done. It’s easy to maintain a connection when you have to be at a place doing a specific list of tasks. Without that constraint, keeping those relationships is difficult.

On the other hand, the end of one chapter leads to the start of another. New people, new challenges, new puzzles. Can’t wait.

Scraping with Cheerio

The Town of Cary maintains a historic theater named The Cary. The town also maintains it’s website that lists all the show times. Apparently, they don’t do a great job of using the data to it’s fullest potential. The Code for America brigade that I help out at wants to parse out that data and create a front end experience that is more helpful to potential customers.

I started with figuring out how to scrape a page with Cheerio. It’s amazingly easier than I thought it would be. The problem is with the structure of the page. As I’m building the scraping module, I’m hoping that they don’t change the structure very often, if at all. Without unique attributes to target specific elements, I have to use the structure to find the show time listings on the page.

The show times themselves have a very volatile structure. So, I’m trying to use tools like Moment to figure out what cell has what piece of data. That’s where I am at right now. All of this is in a prototyping stage but I also want to start storing the raw scrapes somewhere… somewhere being MongoDB. The more data points I have, the more accurate my parser will be.

MongoDB

There are so many technologies out there. NoSQL data storage tools alone are a handful. I just got a new machine and I’ve decided that instead of installing every tool I want to learn or use on the computer itself, I will spin up a VirtualBox machine and install it on there instead. It’s a little bit of an overhead as far as installing and using go but the ability to completely turn off a service is worth it to me.

MongoDB, for example, I know will not be taking up system resources when the VirtualBox machine is turned off. Let’s say I need to install MySQL or something similar. I can do the same thing for those. Development of the application still happens on my machine, they just point to the correct IP/Port to access the service.

Having never used Mongo, I’m looking over the documentation on how to do basic save/edits to data. Found a tool called Mongoose for NodeJS.

item.title: Weeknotes 14
item.description:
Week 14

  • New Job

New Job

Most of my “web developer” time has been spent working on products or for a very specific set of customers. I tried freelance in the beginning but didn’t have the experience for it at the time. So, to have the opportunity to not just get some of that “agency” experience but to also work with a company that mirrors my own ideals as far as open source, tools, and community - well, it’s an amazing feeling. My last day with Knowledge Sharing Systems is the the 12th. I start with Bitovi as soon as I can. :)

I find that transitions are awkward and weird. Sometimes you get what people in the military call “figmo” (eff it, got my orders) and you just stop caring. I have to be honest, I do feel like that in some ways which, in turn, makes me feel horrible. I want to care. I want the thing that I create to be its very best. So, I pondered my feelings for a while and realized something important: we owe our amazing jobs to the people that use the things we make.

Well, duh, right? I gave it some more thought, though… I get to build web things because there is a need for them; because there is a demand. Due to that demand, I have amazing opportunites available to me that I wouldn’t have access to otherwise. It’s these people that I want to honor.

Yea, it’s a pretty mushy but it is true. All I’m saying is, if the work sucks, fine. But don’t stop giving it 100% just because it sucks - it’s being built because people have a need for it and they deserve your best.

I had a lot of fun at my job, lot’s of interesting, fun, and challenging puzzles. I’m just ready to move on to the next set of challenges, I think.

item.title: Weeknotes 13
item.description:
Week 13

  • Perfomance
  • CanJS

Perfomance

The idea of performant JavaScript is not a dormant subject nor an unexplored one. I run into things all the time that teach me how to write faster JavaScript. The problem I found out recently, though, is that the tips I find are usually tips on how current code can be faster. Like looping through an array backwards (from length to zero) or using arrays to concatenate.

Not having a computer science degree (and I’m not really certain the two are linked, but it sure feels like they are), I had not heard of Big O notation before. But this is the kind of stuff I want to learn when it comes to writing better JavaScript. When it comes to writing code, I try to focus on making it readable along with making it fast and making it the right solution. Striking a balance between these is difficult as it is. Arriving to the balanced solution is increasingly difficult when training on one or many of the different parts is absent. For me, for example, I obviously suck at performant JavaScript. I think I do pretty good with making it readable. Research, tests and other reviews will tell me if the solution is correct - so that’s pretty good too.

The point is, though, as our skills continuously evolve, we’ll unlock discoveries and knowledge that allow us to continue improving. It’s like a skills tree in a video game, you can’t unlock some parts of the tree without first unlocking other parts. But with every unlocked skill, we get that much better in a fight.

CanJS

I visited my wife at work last week and noticed that they were using this big binder to keep track of their schedules. I examined some of the sheets and found hand written corrections and notes. I wondered how could they possibly not experience situations where people arrive to work at the wrong times… or days?! I thought I could help out by working on a scheduling app using Firebase and CanJS. Two tools I’ve been itching to really commit to for a while now.

I chose CanJS a while ago because of it’s small foot print. After working with it (and after working with Ember a month ago), I’m still pretty happy with CanJS. It’s pretty straight forward, although I think that some of the training materials are outdated. The documentation helps with this as it’s easy to read and very concise. I’ll add more updates as I go along.

item.title: Warriors
item.description:
Warriors of the Code

We are the Warriors of the Code. We are dedicated, strong, merry, and in search of glory. Often we find ourselves engaged in such glorious battles. It is in these battles that warriors fall, advances hard fought, and the days long and tiring. But we are destroyers and carpenters! We hunger for challenges. We thirst for knowledge! Victory and glory is assured for those that follow the elite, the Warriors of the Code!

Today is the 28th of July. I fear how difficult this will be to write just before the day my friend passed away, but I need to write this; it needs to be a thing.

It’s ironic that I write this in Sublime - he defended it’s strengths to me. The lighting is dark in my room except for a white light above my desk, the perfect amount of light for working at night, really. All things on my desk perfectly visible, notes scribbled on index cards, scattered across my desk; this morning’s empty mug of coffee; and a notebook opened to a page with the words “Warrior of the Code”.

Years ago, he would leave his desk for a meeting or go grab something to eat or go speak with one of our analysts. Every time, he left his computer unlocked. Little horns would slowly peek out from the crown of my head as I snuck over to his cubicle. The actions of my trademark prank were down to a muscle reflex - I would activate the impaired vision theme in Windows and lower the resolution of his monitors, then run like hell. Upon his return, I struggled to keep a straight face, sometimes I gave myself away and we would laugh. Other times he would wake his computer and we would laugh.

Those were good times. He was such a good sport about it all. The conversations we would have on best practices, relationships, race, life… the future. Always that grin on his face and always a baseball cap covering his dome. Always.

His viewing was surreal. My mind battled the truth that my senses explained. That person lying there? He wasn’t smiling but it was him. I knew that he was gone and so were the smiles. So were all the thoughtful and frank discussions.

There lay my friend’s empty shell.

A Warrior of the Code, though, for all eternity.

The quote in the beginning was written a year ago. The Warriors of the Code was created the week after he died, if only in my heart.

Part of me fears the status of his everlasting soul. Part of me is angry - he had no right to take away his potential from the world he was born into. Part of me is content knowing that I was his friend, even for just a sample of the time he lived. Every part of me, though, believes that he lived with such passion and direction.

He loved his music. He loved the web. Both things he did with all of his energy. One of our last deep conversations he said something that has never left me:

“… You can go where the legacy is and be part of something great or you can stay where you are, create your own legacy now and make something great.”

I argued with him. Sometimes you have to move on. Sometimes you need something new. We agreed on one thing though, it is up to you to create your own legacy, to make something great.

The day he was buried, I promised myself to live what I always knew was right. I would create my own legacy and I would make something great. For me first, but in part for my friend as well.

Two years ago today, my friend made his final choice - he left us what he could and took the rest with him. But what he left the people around him isn’t worthless or frivolous; he left us the best part of himself. That smile of his, that energy - his spirit! It’s that spirit that I fall back to on difficult days.

Daniel Walker was a good man. I called him my friend. I miss him. You should, too.

Depression, mental health, and suicide are important subjects. One that I feel our country does not take seriously at all. Please make yourself aware of warning signs. If you are considering suicide, please call 1-800-273-8255.

Word Problems

I was given a programming word problem to solve this week. It has been a long time since I have worked on word problems, let alone a programming specific one. The problem used typical programming problem tropes, yet I found myself doing a good deal of research to solve. It was exciting to be challenged that way - it’s been a while. Wakanda 9

This week was end of sprint so I was focused on that much of the week. We’re taking a week off to catch up on admin stuff, work on some prototyping, and explore Wakanda 9. At first, we were thinking of implementing it straight out, but after a little research, we realized it wasn’t an actual release; it was in their “stabilization channel”. I’m not sure what that means, but they also have a “production channel” which is still pointing to Wakanda 8. Because of this, we assumed that Wakanda 9 is a release candidate at best, a beta product at worst. Either way, not ready for production yet.

Wakanda 9 removed a lot of deprecated stuff. Stuff that we were using because of Wakanda’s poor documentation. For example, I tried using the newer data storage events but couldn’t get them to work. I then flipped over to the deprecated versions and they worked perfectly. The documentation is confusing and poorly written, unfortunately. We often have to bring out the hammer to get things to work. This is bad for obvious reasons, but it’s also a good thing. It is a good thing because it’s an awesome way to learn. Having to pave your own way, without a guide or a map? It’s exploration at it’s purest! That doesn’t mean I think it’s an efficient way, I just think it’s fun sometimes.

item.title: First Meetup Presentation
item.description:
First Meetup Presentation After Action Review

I first heard of an AAR (After Action Review ) from my wife while she was in the Army. Years later, I joined a team that used the Agile method and became accustomed to sprint retrospectives. I like the retrospective concept as a method of reviewing the self and the team.

I’ve said before that this journal’s purpose is partially to help me improve and learn. I meet a lot of people that are afraid to voice their thoughts for fear of being wrong and coming off as a fool. I am one such person. But I never feel that people expressing their thoughts, no matter how raw that thought is, that they themselves are fools. It takes strength and courage to put yourself out there.

In these situations, though, one needs to look critically at one’s performance and be brutally honest in order to improve. I hesitated for a moment about putting my thoughts on the Meetup, I’m pretty embarrassed about my performance. I then remembered the spiel I give to many people about learning web design and development, failure is growth! I immediately decided that I need to be candid about my feelings, thoughts, and decisions regarding my presentation.

I am using the format I found on Wikipedia for AAR. They use slightly better verbiage than I would have used. :)

Grunt/Gulp Meetup AAR

Ok. Here we go… :D Most of these are my own opinions, many people said it was good (which was very kind of them to say, but I think they were being TOO kind. Thanks to all who said so, though. I really appreciate the kindness!). I could be off on some of this stuff… but I really doubt it. ;)

What was supposed to happen

  • I had slides with examples and some step-by-step processes for learning and using Grunt and Gulp. I was supposed to run through the slides, use my notes for help (if needed), and run through the examples in between some of the slides.
  • The slides and my speech would help guide attendees attention from one concept to the next. With each slide, we were to build on the previous concept, ultimately working up to an automation task using Gulp and Grunt.
  • On some slides, I had queues that would tell me when to flip over to command line or Sublime (text editor) to go over the examples.
  • At the end of the slides, I would go over any more examples and questions the audience had.

What happened

  • I set up the PC to display in extended mode. The slideshow on the project and my notes on my screen.
  • I started off OK. Jumped straight into the slides was doing fine.
  • The extended mode caught me off guard, I practiced using one monitor so I assumed everyone could see what I was seeing.
  • I could gauge the audience’s response to some things I would say. I saw blank stares, confused stares, or bored stares. I tried to adapt to this by trying to explain some extra detail of whatever concept I was explaining at the time.
  • I got ahead of my slides when going through some command line code - before I had set up the concepts for the step I had mistakenly moved on to.
  • I remembered some of my queues to flip over to a different application, not all of them. I stammered when this happened.
  • The text from command line, Sublime, and Far were too small on the projector.
  • I digressed… A LOT.
  • I explained a concept and moved on to the next… abruptly.
  • I felt like I struggled explaining the concepts even though I understand them and use them all the time.
  • I was flipping between a command prompt (which I did not intend to use), Far Manager, and Sublime… a LOT.
  • There was a storm that knocked out the power momentarily. At this point, I switched to mirrored mode for the display.
  • The overall theme of the presentation changed as we went along, making it unclear and confusing.

There’s probably a lot more but it all falls under the same stuff above.

What are some improves

  • Practice explaining the core concepts before even working on the slides.
  • Write the entire presentation as a blog article first. I get my thoughts out better in writing, so an article should be the start of the presentation.
  • I practiced by myself, maybe practice in front of people? Like friends, perhaps?
  • I practiced the transitions from slides to text editor, but it was not in a “live” mentality; I would say to myself “and switch to sublime here”… instead of actually doing it.
  • Have queues that tell me to flip BACK to the slides.
  • Practice the examples more.
  • I actually volunteered to do just Gulp. It was recommended to do Gulp and Grunt. This was a great idea, but I am not familiar with Grunt like I am with Gulp. I should have agreed but asked to do my talk in two months instead of the one. This would have given me more time to become familiar with Grunt.
  • Practice. Practice. PRACTICE…. THEN PRACTICE AGAIN.

What are some sustains

I’m having trouble with this section…

  • Um… I think I had pretty good eye contact?
  • I think that I know my tools pretty well. I was nervous, but I know how to use Sublime and command line. I didn’t hesitate with those except when I couldn’t see the result during the time I was using “mirrored” mode.
  • I feel like I gave honest answers to audience questions.
  • I don’t take myself too seriously in public, which, I hope, makes people feel more comfortable.

What can I do differently next time

  • Be honest about an achievable time line. This I had to learn. I don’t think I could have known that I would not have been able to become familiar with Grunt in that time. But, now I do. So, next time, be frank about needing more time.
  • Practice. EVERY. DAMNED. DAY. I think I practiced a lot, but I made changes with almost every run through. I wonder if part of my problem was that I should have gotten to the point where changes were minute or nonexistent before I could say I was actually practicing. Either way, I think practice would have made this go way more smoothly as I can just run through things instinctively without having to think hard about my next step.
  • Practice with an 800*600 screen, make sure anything I am going to display (especially if it has text) that it is bumped up to as large as possible, so everyone can see.
  • Use black on white text? I think projectors with poor lighting display this better. Command line, Sublime, and Far all had dark backgrounds and white text.
  • Don’t use an “extended” display mode. Stick to mirrored!
  • Have a basic slide and example ready before volunteering for a meetup.
  • Invite friends over for dinner, then sucker them into listening/watching my practice. :D
  • Record myself during practice
  • Record myself during actual presentation.

Final thoughts

So, it sounds like I’m saying I didn’t practice enough. Seems legit.

A while back, I went to a meetup where the speaker was, well, not that great. As I thought this, though, I immediately thought that this person is up there giving a talk… which is more than I have done. A friendly person echoed that statement to me right after I finished and it raised my spirits. Sure, I sucked, but I did it. I finished. And, by gum, I’ll improve!

I also wanted to note that everyone’s general friendliness is another reason why I am excited to be a web developer. Nothing but encouragement from people - it’s a great feeling to have supportive peers.

item.title: Weeknotes 11
item.description:

Grunt/Gulp Talk

I did my talk. If I measured the success of a talk in that I didn’t run out in fear and didn’t get “boo’d” off the “stage”… then I succeeded! I take that as a personal failing and it inspired me to write a After Action Review. I’ll post that up later today.

Consolidated sites to Digital Ocean

Digital Ocean doesn’t have redundancies and, so far, they seem to have issues more often than not. It is marketed as a developer VPS solution, which, to me, says stability is not to be expected. And you know what? That’s ok. It’s good enough and it is insanely cheap. The sites that I put on there aren’t popular even by any definition, so if they go down even for a few hours here and there, it should be fine. If they grow in popularity (ha! Right…) then it will make more sense to move them over to something else. Maybe AWS or A Small Orange (they have a similar plan at $20 but with redundant hardware, for example).

Digital Ocean has a ton of great guides for installing all sorts of things. Ghost 0.5 was just released so they are missing the updated version number, but the process is the same. I learned how to have multiple Ghost instances running under one NginX server and how to configure them all as services. I love their “droplet” interface as well. Even with having to use command line for the server itself, their interface is so much easier to use then cPanel (I was told that you can install a GUI and use that to admin the server, but I’m starting to like command line!). Here’s a referral sign up link if you’re interested, which you should be. :)

Explored Laddr

Laddr is nifty PHP app that helps Code for America Brigades keep track of their projects, conversations, and other stuff. It was created as a Code for America project (I think?) in Philadelphia. As I said before, I’m helping out with the Cary Brigade and the first area I’m helping out with is the front end to the Brigade’s website. item.title: Weeknotes 10
item.description:
Week 10

  • Grunt/Gulp Talk
  • Meditation and rest

Missed my Friday deadline

I like to have these written by Friday night, just as a personal goal. I’m a little stressed out on my first talk next week, but I’ll get to that. I feel like it’s ok to miss deadlines from time to time, provided that it isn’t a common occurrence. The problem, I think, we run into when we’re late on something is trying to get caught up. We’re so busy that falling behind on one thing puts everything else behind as well. That’s why it’s important to build a buffer or… wait for it… a graceful fallback! :D

At work, we have periodic “non-sprints” where we aren’t in a sprint and aren’t expected to complete story points. We can work the backlog or do some research on backlog items. I’m no agile expert, so I don’t know how close this follows the agile method or if the terms are correct. Anyway, I think that in anything we do, it’s important to be able to do one of two things (or both, really): claim to do bankruptcy or have a non-work week. I’m not behind on my personal projects… or work projects for that matter, but being late for my weeknotes made me think about it.

Grunt/Gulp Talk

I’m practicing my talk for this Tuesday the 12th. I’m psyched. I’m nervous. I want to get back to Code for Cary so I’m excited for two reasons. Being able to share my thoughts on Gulp/Grunt/automation, but also be able to redirect my attention to other things. Being my first talk, I’ve given this a lot of attention. I’m not complaining, it’s just the fact of the past few weeks. Anyway, I’m planning on throwing the talk and all my materials, including articles I researched for the talk, on github.

Meditation and rest

Along with being able to take a non-work work week or being able to claim task bankruptcy, it’s also important to have complete non-work time. Along with doing mind dumps, I have started doing meditation and introspection time. Straight up sleep is still a work in progress but it’s high priority.

I learned meditation in an Aikido class I took a long time ago and I liked the peace and tranquility I got from it. It’s a struggle trying to keep your mind clear, but it’s a good healthy struggle. Keeping balance in your mind is like a muscle that one needs to exercise in order for it to work efficiently.

Once my mind is clear (ish… I still can’t really achieve complete calmness), I will do a mind dump. I just write down every thought that comes back. Some thoughts are “to dos”, some are ideas, and some are personal introspections. It’s these personal thoughts that I am going for. Understanding why I think things or why I have problems in certain parts of my life are very important to self improvement.

What does this have to do with software? Software engineering is problem solving. Problem solving is a muscle, too. It requires higher reasoning and a balanced mind, in my opinion, which some people have inherently, or, like me, have to work hard at it. I found that meditation and introspection help improve your ability to focus and problem solve.

It also makes you feel better. :)

item.title: Wakanda Data Import
item.description:
Wakanda Data Import Tool

When new data is created to support the application, not user data, we need a way to update servers down the deployment chain. With SQL, this was easy… ish. A versioned query that was part of the deployment handled the task. With Wakanda, we could do the same thing. OR we could take a step higher.

I was tasked with creating a bare bones rights engine for our app. In it, I had to display error messages to the user. I don’t like hardcoding messages, I prefer to let the client edit them whenever possible. I created the solution for this but then ran into a problem syncing data across development and test servers - which meant we were going to run into a problem syncing the data to production… once we reached that point.

So, I created a Datastore class method that checked for a JSON file and imported any required data into the target datastore. It worked great. A couple of issues did come up like exposing the method to the client and abstracting the schema of the table from the import process.

Having the method exposed to the client is dangerous for many reasons, most importantly being that our team is still new to Wakanda, which is also still in its infancy. The solution is to be able to call the method from the server itself. Or easily disable the method once the app is in “production” mode.

The schema part I’m still debating on how to handle. I can include the schema in the import file. I could verify the schema based on the key/value pairs in the data itself. The main task is complete and was approved so the next time I have to do something similar, I’ll go in and clean it up.

Wakanda Training

Wakanda training (Wakanda being based on a JavaScript stack) was 90% JavaScript. It was a good refresh for myself and a very good one-oh-one-esque course for some of our “desktop” developers.

item.title: Weeknotes 6

  • More Meetups

More Meetups

I try to go to as many Meetups as I possibly can. There are many in Durham for topics such as JavaScript and more. Unfortunately, those Meetups are a bit more difficult for me to make consistently. Crop, Function Pink, Web Design, and (now) Code for Cary I try my hardest to make, wherever they are held. Triangle JavaScript is also a good one.

I am helping out the Code for Cary brigade which is fun. I made a comment on my first Meetup with them that there aren’t enough “doing” Meetups, just lots of “conversation” or “presentation” Meetups - which is fine, but we definitely need more “doing” Meetups.

The Web Design Meetup asked for presentations and I thought now would be a good time to put up. I have learned a lot regarding Gulp and I figured doing a presentation is the next step in my progression. So, I volunteered. I need to create a brief and send it to Pepper and hopefully she and her fellow organizers will like it. In addition to the existing projects I wrote about the other day, I now have added a presentation to the list. Good times! No sarcasm there, I love this stuff!

Publishing through Wintersmith with Gulp

I updated the script after finally getting Aspell properly installed on my machine. I’m not sure if I did something wrong during install (I don’t think I did) but the system path wasn’t updated with the Aspell bin location.

With added spell checking support, I also improved the Gulpfile with better handling of articles as they move through my workflow. I need to clean it up a bit and then update the Gulpfile Gist.

I’d also like to make a web interface for it that let’s me edit and process the spell check results in the browser. Add that to the backlog, I suppose.

Github thought/question

I work from either master or from a branch I create (typically dev). New versions or releases come as tags. I don’t see the benefit to keeping versions in their own branch. New work, fixes, or sandboxes: yes, but not old versions. This is all raw thought; I haven’t done any research on this yet, so I could be wrong. Still, when I find a repo that uses this, I would expect the most recent version to be set to master, not some version in the middle.

I found a repo that I needed for work and I noticed that the master branch seemed odd. The structure didn’t match what I was using in their commercial product. I submitted an issue without looking through their branches. If I had, I would have found that the stuff I was looking for was in a branch. I feel like there should have been a readme.md file to explain their structure and the product itself. I admit, I should have looked through the branches first. I still think it’s a weird way to structure a repo but it is on me to look before I leap. Lesson learned.

Lastly, this same repo’s owner left a comment on a prior issue that the project’s bug tracker was elsewhere. Yet, Github’s issue tracker was on. It just makes me feel like they put stuff on Github to attract attention to the product - which is perfectly fine, but if this is the business plan, ya’ gotta commit 100% (no pun intended). People should create a mental model quickly and with little effort.

I could be wrong on all of this but I doubt I am wrong on everything… just some of it. :)

item.title: Project Mind Dump
item.description:
I suffer from “Oh shinny” disease. Symptoms include taking on too many new projects, tasks, or challenges. There is no cure, but symptoms can be alleviated somewhat by sitting down and doing a mind dump.

I use mind dumps to get everything out onto something I can organize and prioritize. In this case, in keeping with the purpose of the Dev Journal, I want to keep myself accountable for what I have taken on. So, I’m also including a quick status update on the different projects I’ve started within the past couple months.

WordPress via Yeoman

I originally wanted to create a simple web app for an data import I am working on. My first goal was to install WordPress using Yeoman. That worked great. The next goal was to be able to initiate a simple PHP web server for development using the install location as the web root. This proved difficult due to my limited understanding of the built in PHP web server, MySQL server, and XAMPP. I did eventually get that to work.

The last goal before actually being able to start working was to understand how to access data within the WordPress tables using nothing but the WordPress API’s (maybe some plugins, if needed). This is where work ceased on this project. I found that my time was better spent learning Ember.js and building an app that way. Still, I would like to establish a good workflow using WordPress. Something that includes a PHP web server, MySQL server, and anything else one would need to work with WordPress.

I’ll look to Bower for this and report back… when I can. This is low priority.

Gulp and Publishing via Wintersmith

I mentioned before why I’m not a fan of Grunt. Things like “streams” and “vinyl” files confuse me a bit but I still prefer Gulp over Grunt. Maybe that is due to my style.

I worked a good deal on my script that helps publish articles with Wintersmith. There are two items left on my To Do list, getting the spell check working and more awareness of what articles are actually published.

This is still ongoing and it’s actually very rewarding. I was not aware of streams and it’s a good way to learn more about Node.js.

Code for Cary page

I attended a meetup and offered my assistance with some of their front end problems. I thought the page was great as Robert, the creator of the page and co-captain of the Code for Cary brigade, said he learned how to implement a new script that used a slider affect when the user scrolls the page. We always focus on whether a page (or product) is good based on the experience for the end user is. This is a good measure but it’s not the only one. Learning how to use something and when to apply it is a success. The end user may not like it which is a failure according to that first measure but even that is useful. Failures are only a failure if you don’t learn from it.

I digress. I’m updating the page and really want to use LESS instead of straight CSS. I’m still working on this as well. This is actually number one.

Writing moar…

I like writing. I love it. I suck at it, though. I suck at web development, too, though. And this journal’s purpose is to help me learn web development as much as it is to help me learn to write more better. (I did that on purpose…)

I write in a few different places which may contribute to the problem of not writing more often. Although, I don’t feel like three places is a lot.

I write about creativity in one spot, video games in another, and web dev here. Not too bad. My goal is one article a month for each site. With as many minor posts as possible. This, in case you were wondering, is a minor post. :)

I really just need to shut up and write more. This is an ongoing thing, too.

Mentoring

Like I said, I’m not that great. I don’t have my own agency, I haven’t organized my own conference, or made any major contributions to the community really. I made peace with my inability to keep up with others skill-wise. I know the saying, there is always someone smarter than you, but that’s not what this is about. I’m ok with not being an expert at anything. That doesn’t mean stop learning or trying my best, it just means that I measure my success against myself. I know what I am capable of now and I know what success looks like to me.

Success looks like helping others develop their skills and confidence. I meet a lot of people just entering the field with that deer-in-headlights look. They want to know where to start and they’re scared because nothing makes sense. Been there. I remember it clearly. I remember thinking how much I would benefit from a mentor. There are plenty of places to ask questions and get guidance on-line, but let’s be honest, we can be a bunch of jerks sometimes. I’m getting rant-y so I’ll just finish by saying that we need a better mentoring system. One that doesn’t require an initiate to have loads of cash (as much as those programs are worth the investment, not everyone has the time or finances to apply).

I’m doing research on how I can help. Again, I’m not one of the “greats” by any means, but I got heart, yo.

item.title: Week Notes 4
item.description:
Week Notes #4

Traveled this week which means two things. Got nothing done and learned that I can get a lot of nothing done with an iPad.

Being nomadic is an interesting concept for a distributed workforce. I work from home and don’t venture out to coffee shops or other remote areas so traveling while still meeting other obligations is an interesting challenge. Unfortunately, the obligations I’m talking about are work related; I wasn’t able to work on my own leveling up.

I was able to use this whole experience as an experiment on working nomadically. First of all, my work laptop failed miserably - the wireless card is crap on this laptop. Thanks to GIT, I was able to do work, do some minor testing (our app requires access to a remote database), and commit locally. However, I wasn’t able to push my commits to Github.

For our standups I used Zoom on the iPad. In fact, the iPad turned out to work out very well for writing code and other tasks like writing documentation or updating Jira. After a few hours of fiddling with the laptop, I gave up and switched to using the iPad completely. My work is backed up to Dropbox but since only the iPad could access the web, the little work I churned out via the laptop was not backed up right away.

Although there doesn’t seem to be a native/easy way to commit or push from the iPad, I could have used my work desktop via Citrix. I don’t like the idea of relying on a remote machine. There are many possible failure points: the computer itself, the network it’s on, the Citrix server, and everything in between. This is really the only chink in the armor but it’s a chink that is hard to hit (this metaphor isn’t working for me…).

I was thinking of doing some SASS/LESS work in Wakanda this week. One task requires me to do some CSS work and thought it would be a good time to bring in the last piece of the puzzle. I am using Gulp to compile CoffeeScript, so using LESS was next on my “To Do” list anyway. Should be fun.

item.title: Week Notes 2
item.description:
Week Two

Worked with Gulp. Field Notes are awesome! Fiddled with Yeoman to install WordPress locally.

I like Gulp more than Grunt.

I enjoy playing with command line but I’m not a fan of using it heavily for certain tasks. That aside, my biggest problem with Grunt is the unstandardized way that people can set configurations for tasks. Using a tilde or a dash and a specific keyword can modify a plugin in many ways. Sometimes these commands are documented sometimes you have to look over their code. Again, I have no problem with sifting through code (when required) but documenting your product is an important part of delivering the product. Gulp’s m.o. is to focus on code over configuration. Loads easier to work with. In fact, I was able to create a script to process my entire publishing workflow with Wintersmith. It’s not a 100% but it will get there.

I use Field Notes for a lot of stuff. I’ve converted the wife even! From a design stand point, they are a lot of fun to collect and even more of a delight to use. I am so excited to see a larger version come out in the limited edition Colors items. Ordered a few extras above what I already get from my subscription.

Yeoman is my next project. I am creating a quick app with WordPress and I’m looking for a quick way to get started. I was hoping Yeoman would be my one stop shop but it looks like I still need to do some extra work. Not too big of a deal if I learn how to use Yeoman better. Afterwards, I’d like to make my own generator.

item.title: Publishing Wintersmith with Gulp - Version 1
item.description:
Unfortunately, I didn’t get all of my must-have items but I was able to get most of them.

The Gulpfile does all of my bare minimum tasks except for one thing - committing and pushing to the github pages repository. Since I have my versioning split into three different repos and the gulp-git module assumes that the location of the gulpfile is the repository home (I think…), it fails since I don’t have a repo there.

I was hoping to change the current working directory to the actual repo folder but I’m not sure how or if this is possible.

The rename module is a life savor for working with Wintersmith. Moving articles from my articles folder to the wintersmith folder was easier than I originally thought.

The run-Wintersmith module was a bit tricky. I’m not certain why but npm was erroring out during install. I added wintersmith as a dependency to my gulpfile and copied the index.js and package.json files manually to the incomplete folder within node-modules. It’s a hack but it works; I can successfully run wintersmith.build().

The very next step is to get git working. Right after that is spell checking. Later on, I’d like to add better handling of the articles.

My articles/published folder should always win. In other words, the wintersmith/content/articles folder should match only what is in the published files and nothing more. During testing, a draft article snuck in my wintersmith folder even though it wasn’t in my published folder. This should be rare once I’m done testing but I’d still like to catch it instead of having a draft article get published.

Until then, I am currently running git commands manually. This isn’t that big of a deal as my main purpose was to have an article structure that could be managed easily.

Wintersmith kind of kills me in that I can’t group articles in a folder. I wanted to have articles grouped by year, for example. So, a blog post from 2013 would show up as domain.com/2013/my-blog-post/. If it can do this, I have not found how. Wintersmith does not support drafts - which actually makes sense, I’m just surprised I haven’t seen many solutions for this.

Either way, the script provides about 70% of what I set out to do, so I’d call this a solid and productive day.

item.title: Learning Gulp, Wintersmith tasks
item.description:
I like command line but as a consumer of some products, I prefer a GUI. Automated tasks runners like Grunt and Gulp, in my opinion should have a GUI for consumers (read: developers). I’ve seen some early work and attempts but nothing very usable. So, here I am learning one of them because, through all my complaining, I do need to learn them.

I like learning a new thing by implementing it in something I am already working on. I figured automating some of my dev journal workflow made sense. Since Wintersmith doesn’t really do drafts, I figured Gulp could help out a bit. So, I worked out the tasks that I think I need in order to make publish easier via Github Pages and Wintersmith.

Not all the steps are required right now, like testing each published article for example. In fact, some of these steps I’d like to wrap as a plugin. But that’s for later.

I started out with the following file structure:

  • dev_journal - root
    • articles - holds markdown articles
      • drafts
      • scheduled
      • published
    • github_pages - “production”
    • wintersmith - holds published articles and template
      • build
      • template
      • content

There are three git repos, one for the root articles folder, one for the wintersmith\template folder, and one for the github_pages folder. I could probably consolidate these down to two, maybe even one repo but I’m doing this in baby steps. :) All of the gulp and package files live in root.

The tasks are written out with every step I want in my workflow. But I don’t have the time to learn and get all of it working so I’m focusing on the moving of files first. I will fine tune and improve as I go along.

Gulp Task: Process Drafts

  • Grab all files from articles/drafts
  • Check spelling and grammar. Do not continue processing file if errors exist but save a copy of it to articles/drafts with spelling/grammar suggestions.
  • Check metadata of file. Wintersmith has the metadata header which has a few required fields. Do not continue processing file if errors exist.
  • Move remaining files to articles/scheduled folder. If the header is filled out then it’s ready to be published.
  • Commit changes to the articles folder.

Gulp Task: Process Scheduled Articles

  • Grab all files from artciles/scheduled
  • Spellcheck each file. Create a copy of any file with errors. Move original and copy to articles/drafts folder.
  • Create folders in wintersmith/content/articles based on file names of each markdown file.
  • Copy each file into its respective folder.
  • Rename each file to “index.md”
  • Run wintersmith build, verify no errors.
  • Commit changes to the articles folder.

Gulp Task: Publish to Github Pages

  • Clear github pages folder (except .git)
  • Copy wintersmith/build folder to github pages folder.
  • Commit changes to github_pages repo.
  • Push changes to GitHub.
  • Wait a few moments (for github pages to update). Maybe this can be a separate task?
  • Check each article to make sure it exists at url and that content is correct.
  • Move scheduled files to the published folder, if they were indeed published.

item.title: Blocking Right Click Is Just Bad
item.description:
My uncle’s family owns their own successful restaurant back in California. Really great Mexican food. Most dishes are authentic to the area they are from back in Mexico. Other dishes are hybrids to cater to different tastes but it’s all good grub!

Anyway, every now and then, I’ll look at websites of people I know and look for stuff to mock and cajole. By mock and cajole, I mean to say, analyze and learn what NOT to do.

The exciting part is to see their site using a more mobile first approach. The site is responsive, albeit a little clunky. Even the obvious stock photography isn’t that bad.

I was impressed. So, here I go to try and look up the agency that created the site. I scroll to the footer, find the typical “Designed by” link and right click on it when suddenly… BOOM. Browser alert message.

Here’s what it says:

XXXXX does not allow you to copy or extract any information and/or images from this website.**PLEASE DO NOT TRY THIS ACTION AGAIN**

I personally know the owners and even I felt a little miffed by the assumption that I was going to steal their horrible stock photos… or the photos of my Uncle with his hugantic cheezer.

Here’s the deal, most users don’t want to steal. Most users might want to print the page using right click. Or, in my case, open a link in new tab. Maybe they want to copy your phone number to the clipboard to save into some phone book application. There are a number of use cases that require the right click which means that by disabling it with a blatantly rude message results in a poor experience for your site and, in turn, your brand.

“What about the people that do want to steal my stuff?” Try this: Hold down CTRL+S. You just stole your stuff. Are you going to block the CTRL key now too? Are you aware that I can disrupt the code that blocks the right click?

You need to understand how the internet works. The browser is receiving files from the internet, specifically a computer somewhere that holds your site. These files are delivered and the connection between the browser and the server is closed. Guess what? Those files now exist on the person’s computer. The user didn’t need to right click to steal them; they’re already there!

People that want to steal photos of my Uncle holding an awesome plate of seafood with the restaurant logo underneath are going to steal it. There is nothing you can do.

What you are doing, though, is creating a bad experience for the legit people.

Final Notes

After reviewing the code that handles the alert, I found this:

if(closeWin=="1") self.close();

If closeWin is set to 1, the tab will close. WOW. You have just fired your customer before they became your customer. You essentially threw away money. Bravo.

Here’s the whole script I mined out of the site. It seems like it is a snippet grabbed from someone else, otherwise I wouldn’t use it without permission.
